subject: Re: About JunitReport
msgSnippet: Hitliubo, ... Its an xls, not a css. You have to use your own XSL stylesheet in stead of the ones from Ant. If you use the single page report, you need to
messageBody:
Hitliubo,

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "hitliubo" <hitliubo@...> wrote:
>
> Thank you very much.
>
> Er, you mean that I can get it by modifying css?

Its an xls, not a css.

You have to use your own XSL stylesheet in stead of the ones from Ant.

If you use the single page report, you need to provide your own junit-
noframes.xsl stylesheet.
If you use the framed report, you need your own junit-frames.xsl.


Ant writes all your system and error output to it's TEST-xxx.xml file.
But it writes it at testsuite level, not at testmethod level.

If you prefix your output in your tests with
[testcaseclassname.testmethodname], you can cunningly forge an xls
stylesheet that only takes output relevant for the current
testmethod, and write the output to the type column.


>
> Thanks.
>
> But I've no idea about css.
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "j_cumps" <j_cumps@> wrote:
> >
> > Hitliubo,
> >
> > The type column shows:
> > - The string you enter in your assertXXX() call.
> > - Stack trace of Exceptions that are thrown during testing.
> >
> > Each JUnit assertXXX() method allows you to pass a text message
as
> > first parameter.
> > This message will appear in the type column, if your assert fails.
> >
> > I don't think there is a standard option to write other text to
> that
> > column.
> > You would have to write your own JUnitReport stylesheet to
achieve
> > this.
> >
> > Regards, Jan
> >
> >
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "hitliubo" <hitliubo@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Junitreport outputs serveral columns that contains:
> > >
> > > Class£¬ Name£¬ Status£¬ Type£¬ Time(s)
> > >
> > > But there's information in type column only assert failed.
> > > Now I want to display some information I need in type column,
> what
> > > should I do?
> > >
> > > Thanks a lot.
> > >
> >
>

Regards, Jan
